dialogues.text: A lordly fellow -- a lordly fellow -- and now you lie on your back with your legs in the air, and you don't even know what the score is -- no, sir, you don't even know what the score is. dialogues.text: Guess you'll be wanting a glass of milk, Amy. She nods. He opens the icebox door and takes out a glass milk which has been standing waiting, covered with a sauc As Amy takes the glass with her right hand, she holds up left thumb,

dialogues.text: That's a fine-looking ring. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: Most surely that was a nice lady to give a ving to a little girl.

dialogues.text: It's a pretty ring.

dialogues.text: I wouldn't be surprised if it were a true wishing ring. Amy looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: A ring that I can wish on like I wished on the candles?

dialogues.text: Maybe, if it's a real mourning ring like we have in Jamaica. All you got to do is turn it on your finger, close your eyes, and make a wish.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (holding) the ring up to him) What's a mourning ring?

dialogues.text: They're given to the living in memory of the dead. If this is a real one -- I can't be sure -- you can make a wish, and it will come true in the twinkling of an eye.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, if it's a real mourning ring,. I'm going to think hard for something I want more than anything else in the world before I wish.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: That's the clever way to do it. Edward looks at her appraisingly. EDWARD (cont'd) You look good and hot and good and tired. Guess you've been playing real hard with your friends.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I'd better tell him. She drinks the remainder of her milk, thinks a moment, an evidently feels it better to get the worst over right awa She starts toward the door.

dialogues.text: This is a pleasant, many-windowed room with a neat array shelves, nail bins, work benches, and small power tools. Amy comes in and stands watching until he has finished.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Your daddy's so pleased with you he's building a model ship for your very own. Come take a look at it. He takes her by the hand to show her the model on the ben Amy looks at it, but she is not particularly happy. Her father's kindness makes it all the more difficult for her tell him what she has to say.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see, when you are a good girl and play with other children instead of moping and dreaming by yourself, your daddy wants to do everything he can to make you happy. This has not helped Amy any. She stands still, staring at him, wondering how to begin. OLIVER (cont'd) How you run along and join your playmates. Turning away from her, he turns on the electric saw. dialogues.text: Daddy -- Oliver looks at her and tries to hear what she is saying cannot because of the noise of the machinery. With an impatient gesture, he turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What do you want. Amy?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you, I wanted to tell you about the other children.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Can't you tell me later?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: But I didn't play with them, Daddy. They wouldn't play with me. Oliver is annoyed at having been interrupted and further angered by the fact that he had jumped to his own conclus of the child's "goodness." dialogues.text: What do you mean you didn't play with the other children?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It was on account of the birthday party.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Because you didn't ask them? I don't blame them for being angry. Why didn't you explain what happened?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: They ran away.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Why didn't you run after them?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I did. I came to an old dark house, and a voice called to me -- a lovely, sweet voice --- Oliver cocks his head apprehensively.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Now Amy Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: And who did the voice belong to?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It was just a voice.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: (completely angry) Now look, this is the last time you come to me with any such stories — I'm sick of this sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Daddy, it's true.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Let me be the judge of that. His voice has been rising. As Amy starts to steal out of workshop into the yard, Alice, dressed for gardening, pok her head in at the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Amy's been lying again.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: (scornfully) Voices from an old dark house!

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Did you hear the child out?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Well, it seemed to me --

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You mean you didn't. It seems to me the least you could do. You can't just jump at conclusions that way. You're being unfair.

dialogues.text: I'm never unfair. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: (roaring) I'm not shouting at you, but there's no doubt in my mind that you spoil this child! Amy, who has been listening intently, shrinking away with mingled embarrassment and hurt, suddenly begins to cry. Oliver is the first to kneel beside her.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Daddy and Mommy are a little upset.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You're upset about me -- I made you fight --I hate for you to fight.

dialogues.text: Amy, still dabbing at her eyes, comes a few feet out of t workshop door and turns back to look at her parents. dialogues.text: (raising her finger to her lips) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Sh! Then you must keep it true. Goodnight, darling. She turns out the lights and goes out the door.
